Wrapt in the shade where meditation lies,</br>And holds a mental intercourse above;</br>Come, truth, and teach a bosom to be wise,</br>Which mourn'd too long for disappointed love.
What art thou — wond'rous impulse of desire,</br>Which blooming hope so pleasingly has drest?</br>Or whence proceeds th' involuntary fire,</br>Which burns so fiercely in the human breast?
Sweet inconsistent off-spring of the sky,</br>The latent cause in tenderness declare;</br>Nor force the heart eternally to sigh,</br>And yet conceal the motive of despair.
If Mira's face in every charm is drest,</br>Why am I doom'd incessantly to pine?</br>Or shall the coldness of another's breast,</br>Create his sharp anxiety in mine?
Alas!  since Being smil'd upon the morn,</br>And nature saw how excellent it rose;</br>Thy race, O man, to misery was born,</br>And doom'd to bear probationary woes.
Too easy nature, indolently kind,</br>From fate's severe restrictions to depart,</br>Gave man a passive tenderness of mind,</br>And beauty's sole dominion of the heart.
But yet the pang of never-hoping love,</br>To time's last moment destin'd to conceal;</br>Is not the only sorrow we must prove,</br>The only sorrow we are doom'd to feel.
A latent train of hydra-headed woes,</br>From life each dearer benefit have stole;</br>Destroy'd the smallest glimmer of repose,</br>And damp'd the choicest blessing of the soul.
Perhaps e'en now, some high distinguish'd name,</br>Rais'd up to grandeur, and enrich'd by place;</br>Starts from some new imaginary shame,</br>Or only slumbers to a fresh disgrace.
Perhaps, now tortur'd on imperial down,</br>Some scepter'd mourner languishes his hour;</br>And sinks beneath the burthen of a crown,</br>The slave of greatness, and the wretch of pow'r.
Some ill-star'd youth, whose melancholy moan,</br>Has vainly sounded in unpitying ears;</br>Now weeps, perhaps, in bitterness alone,</br>And gives a lavish freedom to his tears.
Science, which left him polish'd and refin'd,</br>Has giv'n a new occasion to complain;</br>And knowledge only has enlarg'd his mind,</br>To make it more susceptible of pain.
No hand, alas!  its kind assistance lends,</br>To drive misfortune from his lowly door;</br>For when, O when, did wretchedness make friends!</br>Or who will seek acquaintance with the poor!
Perhaps some virgin is this moment led,</br>All sicklied over with dejected charms,</br>Compell'd to languish in a hated bed,</br>And seem'd quite happy in detested arms.
Wedded to anguish and repining care,</br>Yet bound to wear no sorrow in her eye;</br>And tho' condemn'd for ever to despair,</br>Deny'd the humble privilege to sigh.
How dread a picture meditation brings</br>Of life's unceasing wretchedness below!</br>Where the long chain and ordinance of things</br>Appear so fraught with misery and woe.
Yet rest, my soul, submissively, O rest,</br>Nor think that virtue has been treated hard;</br>This world was made to prove it in the breast,</br>And not alone intended to reward.
The great first cause, all-gracious, has design'd,</br>His endless transports for a world of bliss,</br>To crown a moral rectitude of mind,</br>And bless obedient righteousness in this.
Whatever ills in this uncertain state,</br>Lamenting man may frequently have known;</br>Spring from no wish or negligence of fate,</br>But some unhappy error of his own.
Then, all resign'd, O let him pour his heart!</br>And kiss the sharp, but salutary rod!</br>Nor, tho' condemn'd in bitterness to smart,</br>Presume to throw the blame upon his God.</br>
